title: A Challenging National Math Contest - Normally Distributed Scores
question_text:
The AMC-12A is national math contest which is known to be very challenging. Statistics made available to the public show that the mean score on this contest in 2015 was $69.90$ and the standard deviation was $20.21$. A total of $55{,}833$ students participated and the distribution of scores was approximately normal.
Approximately what proportion of students who participated in the AMC-12A in 2015 had scores below $50$?
solution:
To solve this problem, we must first convert the raw data to a z-score. The formula for calculating z is:

z=

...where x is the observed value or value of interest, μ is the mean, and σ is the standard deviation.

Since we are looking for the proportion of students with a score less than 50

p(z<−0.985)=0.162

We can complete the calculation for p(z<−0.985)
using either the z
-table or the TI83/84 graphing calculator's normalcdf function. The normalcdf function finds probabilities associated with given z
-scores. The syntax is: normalcdf(lower bound, upper bound, mean, standard deviation). In this case you would:

Enter 2nd, DISTR
Choose normalcdf
Enter -10^99, -0.985, 0, 1

Enter again and the calculator will return the value of 0.162
. This is the answer.

Note: If you are using the z
-table to arrive at your answer, you would get a slightly different answer. Since it is not an option, choose the closest value from those provided.
